title: Samsung Z Fold 6 Durability Test - IT STARTED ON FIRE
description: Today we durability test the Samsung Z Fold 6. Get started today at  Chime. Feels like Progress. The Samsung folding phones are always fascinating to me. Flexible screens, transforming form factors, There is so much to learn from Samsung Z Fold 6 durability test and teardown.   Get your Teardown skin here:   The Chime Credit Builder Visa Credit Card is issued by The Bancorp Bank, N.A. or Stride Bank, N.A. Out-of-network ATM withdrawal and OTC advance fees may apply. Terms and Conditions apply. Go to  for details.
transcript: Sorry for the mess. Sometimes these durability tests can get a little dirty. This video is sponsored by Chime, But more on them later. The Galaxy Z Fold 6, at first glance to me anyway, feels a whole lot like the Z Fold 5, and the four, and the three. Samsung has modified the rings around the three camera lenses and made the center crease slightly less pronounced, with its new shear thickening fluid design. Which hopefully we'll see more of in a second. But it still has the same laundry list of warnings that we saw all the way back with the original Fold one. Like don't press too hard keep away from dust and don't take off the screen protector. Which is fine this is arguably the most technologically advanced smartphone on the planet. Even after it not having changed much in the last 3 years. The inner flexible display has an underscreened selfie camera. Which is kind of cool. The exterior display is almost the same size as a regular smartphone, with full functionality. Which makes me wonder if I would have enjoyed switching to the Fold more than the Flip. But I'm not about to change my phone again, cuz once every 3 4 years is enough for me. Starting off with the inner screen scratch test even with this new shear thickening fluid upgrade. The exterior layers of the display starts scratching at a level two with deeper grooves at a level three. And since fingernails horse hooves and elephant tusks are also a three on Mohs scale of hardness. This display would get wrecked by all of those things. Ss a side note something I learned yesterday was that elephants can smell and locate water from over 10 miles away. Which is crazy! The exterior glass is invictus two. Meaning it scratches at a level six with deeper grooves at a level 7. And that front-facing 10 megapixel camera is protected by the same glass. Samsung is calling this the lightest fold ever made. It's a whole half an ounce lighter than its predecessor. For my American audience a half an ounce is about the same weight as 2 quarters. Still made with aluminum though. Except for the 5G antenna location. Up at the top we have a very interesting earpiece loudspeaker opening. The main upgrade of the Fold 6 though, besides it being half an ounce lighter, is that now the three rear camera lenses have textured camera rings. All have that record scratch sound effect ability which is worth $1,900 bucks all by itself right there. Jerry Rig knife not included obviously, you got to buy that separately. The center screen size is the same as last year with the same pixel density. But this year we do have a higher peak brightness which is nice when you're scrolling through fire memes all day. This Fold 6 lasts about 25 seconds under the heat from my lighter. Before the pixels go black and the upper layers of the plastic melt. Another subtle upgrade this time around is that the phone's ingress protection rating actually includes dust. IP48 means that it's protected from dust specs greater than 1 mm in size. And I don't know if you've been outside recently but 1 mm is pretty big when compared to the average granule of dirt. And if we spread copious amounts of this outside stuff all over the hinge and munch on it for a bit. There is quite a bit more grinding hinge noises than there were before. Which is concerning Samsung says that this hinge is rated for 200,000 folds more about 10 years worth of use, but that's obviously in a pristine dirt-free environment. I'm a little queasy knowing that my almost $2,000 smartphone has ingested a harmful substance. It seems like the dust protection is a little bit less protective than it was last year, at least with my own testing. Finally, the bend test with the Fold 6 closed it's obviously a tank. Two slabs sandwich on top of each other aren't bending anywhere. From the back or the front. Opening the Fold 6 though and going backwards shows off a whole lot of flex ,but it does lock out without damaging the display, or the hinge, or the frame. Bending along the crease of the hinge itself, kind of like the iPad, does not yield any catastrophic results. Unlike the iPad. the z Fold 6 survived my durability test. Which means now we can commence the tear down and see how much dirt got captured in inside of that hinge. I do like that the Fold 6 comes with one free screen protector replacement in the first year. And if the screen itself gets toasted which mine is probably going to be, a full screen replacement in the first 2 years, is only $200 bucks. Which isn't that bad. With the professionally replaceable exterior screen protector removed the Fold 6 is still functioning like normal. For now. And remove two more screws one on each corner of the motherboard and the brains at the Fold 6 can come away from the phone. The 12 megapixel ultra wide camera does not have OIS. The main 50 megapixel camera does have a OIS and the 10 megapixel telephoto camera also has Optical image stabilization. The front 10 megapixel selfie camera does not. The vapor chamber inside of the Fold 6 is 60% larger than on the Fold 5. Which is nice. It probably helps out with all the AI and Ray tracing improvements. The upper loudspeaker and earpiece comes out at this point with a blue translucent window. So, that we can see the balls inside of the speaker. The same thing goes for the lower lower loudspeaker. Which for $1,900 bucks it should very much arrive with all the toppings. The newly designed loudspeaker slot at the top of the phone uses the same cavity as the earpiece on the front of the phone. The cavern combines into one rubberized screen mesh that's designed to keep water out. The holes on this mesh are so microscopically tiny that water being all cohesive and stuff would rather cling to other droplets than cheese grate itself into the internals of your phone. However, the deeper the phone gets submerged the more likely that water pressure will overcome the tininess of the holes and allow ingress into your phone. Which is why it's only rated IP48 to a depth of 1 1/2 meters for 30 minutes.
